title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 19 october [1869]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 19 October [1869]
text: 19 Oct 1869tuesdayTuesday October 19 my dear Walteri receevedreceived your letter to day with the money and harpers magsineHarper's Magazine i was glad to have the number and letter too i scarce ever see the magazine now adays but like to read it particularly at present for i have had such a sore thumb on my right hand i couldentcouldn't hardly sew a stich i got a splentersplinter in it before the folks went away and then slopping about in cold water it got so bad i put sliperyslipery elm on it but it didentdidn't doodo much good but it has got so i can use it to day i was so disappointed last saturdaySaturday in Georges not coming home i wanted him to come very much to fix the stove for one thing but Edd and i got it up yesterday i thought we could hardly get it out but we did and its much better it has been quite cold here i got a bushel of coal this morning and it works much better than wood) i haventhaven't heard from st louisSt. Louis since i last wrote to you walterWalter i dontdon't know whether mattyMatty is coming on here this fall or not i dontdon't think it would be good for her i think itsit's too late in the season but if they come we will doodo the best we can) not one of the prices has been here since you went away you know helen was here just before you left and i said i thought she hadenthadn't a very good time i sent a letter to hannaHannah last week a good long letter urging her as much as i thought would doodo to come and makmake us a good vesitvisit that i particularly wanted her to come and that she must write to me as soon as she received my letter without fail and i suppose that will be the last of it i put one dollar in the letter and said i send a little change but will send more next time whether she ever gets any of the letters i dontdon't know) i have had thoughts of sending a line to Dr thayerThayer what doodo you think of it walterWalter doodo you think it would be best or not) maryMary wanted me very much to go to BurlngBurlington and she would stay and keep eddEdd i told her i didentdidn't feel able to undergo the journey) you know maryMary wrote that Ansel they thought failed the business was while they were down in virginiaVirginia he got a drinking and John Louisa sLouisa's husband got very much put out with him and throwed his liquor overboard and they came home anselAnsel come near dying with the deliru tremesdelirium tremes he was master mason in his lodge but is broke and gone down to a common man maryMary and louisaLouisa belongs to the presbeteranPresbyterian church but the change of heart we wontwon't say any thing about she says she is as good as the rest and have a 20 doldollars pew and with Love to all of the OconorsO'ConnorsLWsorry to hear her sister is ill Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 19 October [1869]
